subject: OS-6180 NIC Transceivers should show up in hc topo OS-6181 Want library to parse SFP i2c information Reviewed by: Ryan Zezeski <ryan.zeseski@joyent.com> Reviewed by: Patrick Mooney <patrick.mooney@joyent.com> Approved by: Bryan Cantrill <bryan@joyent.com>
commitMessage:
OS-6180 NIC Transceivers should show up in hc topo
OS-6181 Want library to parse SFP i2c information
Reviewed by: Ryan Zezeski <ryan.zeseski@joyent.com>
Reviewed by: Patrick Mooney <patrick.mooney@joyent.com>
Approved by: Bryan Cantrill <bryan@joyent.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

To see how these different things are used, there are several examples added to the ticket.

Patch Set 2:

Note, I forgot to add a file, sff.h which had constants. That's now there.

Patch Set 2:

(34 comments)

Thanks all for looking at this. I've updated this for the changes and a few minor fixes.
Uploaded patch set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased.
Uploaded patch set 5: Commit message was updated.
Change has been successfully merged by Robert Mustacchi
I think this is a holdover from a previous iteration of this function? It's not used.
In the block comment you mention SFF 8476 and SFF 8636, but this constant uses 8472. I'm not familiar with all this jargon, just wanted to make sure this is right.
The block comment was meant to be SFF 8472. So changing that. Thanks for noticing that.
Was this supposed to be "Not every"?
Any reason in particular to enforce this restriction?
No, I guess not? Mostly how this is factored today. I suspect when this makes it into dladm we can figure out what the right combo was. I think I mostly didn't do it because it didn't seem useful.
With these vars all initialized to NULL, we could consider omitting the on-error assignments to make this more terse.  Up to you.

I had thought about it, but I wasn't sure if I should guarantee that when nvlist_lookup_string() returned a value that it wouldn't have modified the pointer I passed to it. I basically felt I should treat it as undefined.
Do we need an ARGSUSED directive here since several args aren't used?
nit: It appears that there's width to move this up to the preceding line?
Does it make sense to size this array based on SFF_8024_NIDS?  I'm not sure if would (now or maybe later) get any benefit from static analyzers or lint tools.
style nit: The preceding "output" functions place the nvlist at the end of the args.  Maybe this should be consistent in that way too?
OK, I can change it around.
Would it make sense to hard-code uint32_t types here?
I've changed everything except count to be a uint32_t. Hopefully this is what you were referring to.
algorithm nit: using ffs(3c) in a loop like this seems a little odd, since it'll expand out to large(r) loop counts when there are many bits set.  Functionally it looks fine though.
Perhaps this should be "...upper bound on the number of bytes _and_ that is padded to the right...". Otherwise it seems like "that is padded..." is a determiner on "number of bytes".
A comma would help, otherwise the subject reads as "Note spaces".
I've rephrased these. Let me know what you think of the new version.
nit: Maybe name this something like 'fc_val' since it's used only for that one check.
OK. I've changed it here, but I've left the sfp case the same.
Why are we storing to 'ret' here?  It doesn't appear to be used at all.  If elided from these statements, I would move its definition down into the 'else' scope below.
We weren't meant to return it, actually, like in the other cases.
If a val of 0 really means 70C, shouldn't we add 70 to val when passing it so sff_add_unit_string()? I feel like I'm missing something. Perhaps a comment would help.

No, this is correct. If you look at the spec, this basically allows someone to override the case temperature from the default of 70 C. So the logic, I think, is correct. I'll add a comment to clarify what's going on.
This was supposed to be 'Not every'. Does that still need a colon or 'that'?
Erm, yes. I guess it passed mostly by fluke.
I think this is backwards, we failed to find expected value.
Again, I think it's the other way around.
This looks like copy pasta because it mentions "bit rate" and 0xff but we are testing optical parsing here.
